title: Pontardawe Walks Walking Route

images.title: Jaggery / Pontardawe War Memorial
images.caption: Pontardawe War Memorial. Located on the corner of Herbert Street and Holly Street, the War Memorial was unveiled in July 1923.

images.title: John Phoenix / Three bridges at Pontardawe
images.caption: Three bridges at Pontardawe. Old stone bridge between two modern bridges

images.title: Nigel Davies / Footbridge over Tawe in Glantawe Riverside Park
images.caption: Footbridge over Tawe in Glantawe Riverside Park. Despite looking like a rail bridge this is a narrow footbridge linking the layby on the A4067 across the river with the rest of the park.

images.title: John B / Cricket on Pontardawe Recreation Ground
images.caption: Cricket on Pontardawe Recreation Ground. Pontardawe Recreation Ground is on the flood plain of the River Tawe, which is behind the trees on the right of the photograph. The Swansea Canal runs below the houses.

images.title: Ena Dawson / Ynsmeudwy Bridge over canal
images.caption: Ynsmeudwy Bridge over canal

images.title: Alan Richards / Pont dros gamlas / Bridge spanning a canal
images.caption: Bridge spanning a canal. Built by The Swansea Canal Navigation Company between 1794-1798 it carried coal down from the Upper Swansea Valley to the docks in Swansea.

images.title: Jonathan Billinger / Confluence of the Twrch with the Tawe
images.caption: Confluence of the Twrch with the Tawe. Looking south towards the hillside of Y Darren Widdon.

images.title: Adrian Dust / Ynysmeudwy Canal Bridge No8
images.caption: Ynysmeudwy Canal Bridge No8. Dates from 1796-98. Built to a design of Charles Roberts & Thomas Sheasby Senior.

description: This town in the Swansea Valley has some nice riverside and canalside paths to try. This walk from the town takes you along the Swansea Canal and the River Tawe towards Ystalyfera and Gurnos. On the way there's lots of pretty locks and bridges over the canal and river to see. The walk follows the waymarked St Illtyd's Walk for most of the way. This long distance trail could also be followed south through the Crynant Forest part way along the route.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: To continue your walking in the area head to Cwm Clydach National Nature Reserve. There's a wonderful river gorge and lots of interesting flora and fauna to see here. Head west and you can visit Pontarddulais and enjoy a climb to the viewpoint at Graig Fawr. Cyclists can pick up National Cycle Route 43 which runs north to Caehopkin where you link with the popular Celtic trail.

county: Castell-nedd Port Talbot - Neath Port Talbot
